awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research is to advance the understanding of the internal structure of hadrons, which include protons, neutrons, and other subatomic particles described in terms of quarks and gluons. One of the central goals of modern nuclear physics research concerns the 3-dimensional imaging of the internal structure of the proton and atomic nuclei. To achieve the objective the investigator and his students will conduct theoretical and phenomenological projects which aim at revealing the 3-dimensional structure of protons, neutrons, and atomic nuclei in terms of quarks and gluons. This research will advance the development of the theory tools necessary to understand experiments which are in preparation at the Thomas Jefferson National Laboratory, the Brookhaven National Laboratory, and other facilities world-wide. The broader impacts of the research program include training of graduate students and offering research opportunities for undergraduate students, and include outreach activities at a wide variety of levels from K-12 to college level. Public lectures will be given to inform the population of the latest research in nuclear and particle physics, what physicists learn from that, and how the society will benefit from it.

The theoretical tools to describe the internal structure of hadrons in terms of quarks and gluons, the degrees of freedom of quantum chromodynamics, are provided by parton distribution functions which can be accessed in high energy scattering experiments. In order to address 3-dimensional imaging two theoretical approaches are explored: transverse momentum dependent distributions (TMDs), and generalized parton distributions (GPDs). These complementary approaches provide powerful tools to access so far unexplored aspects of the nucleon structure, including spin-orbit correlations of partons and the mapping of strong forces exerted on partons inside the nucleon. The theoretical research will address the flavor asymmetry in the polarized quark sea, TMDs of valence and sea quarks, GPDs and studies of the energy-momentum tensor, and the exploration of chiral symmetry breaking effects for the partonic structure of the nucleon. The applications of this research include mapping of strong forces inside the nucleon, and the description of exotic tetra- and pentaquark hadronic states recently observed at LHC and other experiments. This research will support experimental programs at Jefferson, Brookhaven, and Fermi National Labs, and contribute to the planning of the Electron-Ion Collider, the next generation research facility envisioned by the U.S. nuclear physics community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
It is well known that more than 99% of the mass of the matter in the visible universe is due to protons and neutrons, collectively called nucleons, that make up atomic nuclei. The nucleons are in turn made of quarks bound by gluons. But the detailed microscopic explanation of how the mass and internal nucleon structure arise in the underlying microscopic theory of strong interactions, quantum chromodynamics (QCD), remains an open question. To address this question various approaches have been put forward with the goal to arrive at an imaging of the internal proton structure: imaging in momentum space through studies of transverse momentum dependent parton distribution functions (TMDs) or imaging in coordinate space achieved in terms of two-dimensional or three-dimensional Fourier transformations of generalized parton distribution functions (GPDs) or form factors (FFs). TMDs, GPDs and FFs are properties which entail information about the nucleon structure and can be inferred from different types of high-energy accelerator experiments carried out, for instance, at the Brookhaven or Jefferson National Laboratories. Many aspects of TMDs, GPDs and certain FFs are currently not well known and in many cases nearly completely unknown. In this situation, it is of importance to carry out theoretical studies to learn about their properties, and to test the theoretical understanding in experiments planned in near future at the Brookhaven and Jefferson National Laboratories as well as at the recently proposed large-scale nuclear research facility Electron-Ion Collider which is envisioned to be build within the next decade.

The research carried out in this project has improved the theoretical understanding of the properties of TMDs, GPDs, and certain FFs. The obtained research highlights include calculations of the semi-inclusive deep-inelastic electron-proton scattering or pion-nucleon Drell-Yan processes carried out respectively in the so-called Wandzura-Wilczek approximation indispensable to constrain the numerous unknown TMDs or based on quark models of the pion and nucleon structure. Further intellectual merit includes studies the energy-momentum tensor and the associated FFs with focus on the physical interpretation of these FFs as well as their properties in effective approaches and models of nucleon structure as well as the application of the information contained in energy-momentum tensor FFs to the description of the structure of the recently discovered exotic tetra-quark states. The carried out research program provided also theoretical support for the experimental programs at Jefferson and Brookhaven National Labs and contributed to the planning of the future Electron-Ion Collider facility. Broader impacts include outreach activities and training of young researchers at undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral level contributing to the production of a highly trained future workforce.
